questions.question_text:
A Content Processing team has notified a SysOps Administrator that their content is sometimes taking a long time to process, whereas other times it processes quickly. The Content Processing submits messages to an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) queue, which details the files that need to be processed.
An Amazon EC2 instance polls the queue to determine which file to process next.
How could the Administrator maintain a fast but cost-effective processing time?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
ApproximateNumberOfMessagesVisible metric allows you to trigger scaling actions based on the number of visible messages in the queue. This helps ensure that the system can handle the processing load efficiently and respond to changes in message volume effectively.

Dead-Letter-Queue is for not messages that cannot be processed for some reason.
I`ll suggest option D: ApproxMaxVisibleMessages, as this indicates that messages are not polled by the receiver and need more receivers.

choices.A: Attach an Auto Scaling policy to the Amazon SQS queue to increase the number of EC2 instances based on the depth of the SQS queue
choices.B: Create an Auto Scaling policy to increase the number of EC2 instances polling the queue and a CloudWatch alarm to scale based on MaxVisibility Timeout
choices.C: Attach an Auto Scaling policy to the SQS queue to scale instances based on the depth of the dead-letter queue
choices.D: Create an Auto Scaling policy to increase the number of EC2 instances polling the queue and a CloudWatch alarm to scale based on ApproximateNumberOfMessagesVisible

choices.B: Install the Amazon CloudWatch memory monitoring scripts, and create a custom metric based on the script's results
choices.C: Increase the minimum size of the cluster to meet memory and application load demands
choices.A: Create a custom script that pipes memory utilization to Amazon S3, then, scale with an AWS Lambda-powered event
choices.D: Deploy an Application Load Balancer to more evenly distribute traffic among nodes

questions.question_text:
A SysOps Administrator receives reports of an Auto Scaling group failing to scale when the nodes running Amazon Linux in the cluster are constrained by high memory utilization.
What should the Administrator do to enable scaling to better adapt to the high memory utilization?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
By installing the CloudWatch memory monitoring scripts on the instances in the Auto Scaling group, you can collect memory utilization data. This data can be used to create a custom metric in CloudWatch that reflects the memory utilization of the instances.

Once the custom metric is created, you can configure scaling policies based on the memory utilization metric. This allows the Auto Scaling group to scale up or down based on the memory demands of the application.

The CloudWatch monitoring scripts are deprecated We recommend that you use the CloudWatch agent to collect metrics and logs.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/monitoring-scripts-intro.html

for B, How is it solving the problem? 
Question is "to enable scaling to better adapt to the high memory utilization", cloud metrics is good to monitor not enable scaling, I would go with D

comments.content: default cloud metrics does not have Memory, thus will need to have custom script to send data to be monitored. App ELB will still forward traffic even if memory is high unless instance is marked as unhealthy.

discussion.content: Using a load balancer does not address instances failing to scale based on memory utilization.

questions.question_text:
An errant process is known to use an entire processor and run at 100%. A SysOps Administrator wants to automate restarting the instance once the problem occurs for more than 2 minutes.
How can this be accomplished?

choices.A: Create an Amazon CloudWatch alarm for the EC2 instance with basic monitoring. Enable an action to restart the instance.
choices.D: Create a Lambda function to restart the EC2 instance, triggered by EC2 health checks.
choices.B: Create a CloudWatch alarm for the EC2 instance with detailed monitoring. Enable an action to restart the instance.
choices.C: Create an AWS Lambda function to restart the EC2 instance, triggered on a scheduled basis every 2 minutes.
